body:
I'm going to read spec.md (reading just in spare time, which is little) and then maybe to try to reimplement Tox Protocol based on the specification (just for learning, you know).
As I advance in reading I'm going to fix typos, leave notes and ask questions -- I'll be pushing changes into this PR

Some questions are placed in the paper and marked with "TODO:" prefix

At the moment I'd propose adding goals and threat model part into the beginning of specification, so that it can serve as purpose and intuition for the rest of document and future reimplementations.
I also noted that threat model isn't clearly stated anywhere, which leads to some misunderstandings in discussions (e.g. this rather implicit tradeoff between anonymity and things like realtime AV)

Also I wanted to know if [kademlia](http://pdos.csail.mit.edu/~petar/papers/maymounkov-kademlia-lncs.pdf)'s least-recent-seen eviction policy (see diffs or referenced paper for rationale) was considered and if it was why was it rejected

Also, I disclaim, ugh, everything (see commitmsg for all these "I'm not ...")

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -305,17 +368,18 @@ connect directly to them via UDP.
 ## Distance
 
 A Distance is a positive integer. Its human-readable representation is a
-base-16 number. Distance is an [ordered
+base-16 number. Distance (type) is an [ordered
 monoid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ordered_semigroup) with the associative
-binary operator `+` and the identity element `0`. When we speak of a "close
-node", we mean that their Distance to the node under consideration is small
-compared to the Distance to other nodes.
+binary operator `+` and the identity element `0`.
 
-The DHT needs a [metric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metric_(mathematics)) to
+The DHT uses a [metric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metric_(mathematics)) to
 determine distance between two nodes. The Distance type is the co-domain of
 this metric. The metric currently used by the Tox DHT is the `XOR` of the
-nodes' public keys. The public keys are interpreted as Big Endian integers (see
-[Crypto Numbers](#key-1)).
+nodes' public keys: `distance(x, y) = x XOR y`.
+Public keys are interpreted as Big Endian integers (see[Crypto Numbers](#key-1)).

@@ -325,17 +389,31 @@ without computing the complete integral value. This works, because as soon as
 an ordering decision can be made in the most significant bits, further bits
 won't influence that decision.
 
-The XOR metric `d` satisfies the required conditions:
+The XOR is a valid metric, i.e. it satisfies the required conditions:

comment_data.body: Why? Also, this should now be "The index of the bucket", but then this is exactly the same as "The bucket index", so why the change?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -375,14 +444,15 @@ set, the last (greatest) element is the furthest away.
 
 ### Bucket Index
 
-The bucket index can be computed using the following function:
+The index of bucket can be computed using the following function:

@@ -540,7 +615,7 @@ response has in their list of known nodes.
 
 ### Packed node format
 
-The DHT Send nodes uses the Packed Node Format.
+The DHT Send Nodes uses Packed Node Format.

comment_data.body:
Er, that's right.
Rationale for the change was, as noted in the commit message, that while reading first time I'd been confused  if it was "[The bucket]'s index" or "The [bucket index] of something else contained in bucket"? (though it was possible to derive from context).
I admit, this can be just my misunderstanding of grammar/semantics, as English is not my native

comment_regular_data.body:
[![CLA assistant check](https://cla-assistant.io/pull/badge/signed)](https://cla-assistant.io/TokTok/spec?pullRequest=42)
All committers have signed the CLA.

Thanks, can you check the formatting? Our travis build reformats the code in a canonical way. Perhaps you can adopt its formatting. If you feel that it's doing the wrong thing (i.e. it's producing semantically incorrect code), let me know.
LGTM, can you squash all commits into one, and give it some nice commit message?

commit.message:
some proofreading (begining)

Disclaimer
---------
I am no cryptographer;
And i'm not really familiar
with these "distributed systems" things either;
Just a math student, who happened to be interested and concerned;
I will commit fixes and notes
as i advance in reading spec.md and related papers;
this is is going to be rather slow,
i'm reading it only sometimes in spare time;

Changes, notes and questions:
----------------------------
-   fixed some typos
-   added "goals and threat model" section
    it is supposed to give a reader an idea
    on what problems Tox addresses, so that:
    -   it is clear why and how decisions were made
    -   reader can verify if stated problems are addressed by specification;
    -   knowledge of goals and non-goals can serve a guide for a reader
        making tradeoffs in his own protocol reimplementation
-   updated ##Distance
    -   s/d(x,y)/distance(x,y)/ because this is how it is refered to
        throughout document
    -   added XOR's subadditivity proof
    -   added XOR's unidirectionality
-   proposed consideration of kademlia's least-recently-seen eviction
    policy instead/in addition to current policy of chosing closest node
